questions.text: A patient developed relative bradycardia. All of the following can be the cause except
Match the List I with List II and select the correct answer using the code given below the lists:
A 40-year old woman presents with sudden onset palpitations. An ECG done reveals narrow QRS complex tachycardia. The most likely diagnosis is:
Which of the following does NOT cause prolongation of QT interval?
While distinguishing a venous pulsation from the arterial pulsation in neck, which of the following is NOT correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The height of venous pulse varies with respiration

options.label: B
options.text: Abdominal pressure causes rise in venous pulse

options.label: C
options.text: Venous pulse has a single peak in each cardiac cycle

options.label: D
options.text: Venous pulse is not easily palpable

questions.correct_answer: C. Venous pulse has a single peak in each cardiac cycle

questions.text: Which one of the following is the minimum spirometry criterion for diagnosis of bronchial asthma?

options.label: A
options.text: Decrease in FEV1 ≥ 20 % after 6 minutes of exercise

options.label: B
options.text: Increase in FEV1 ≥ 12 % following administration of inhaled bronchodilators

options.label: C
options.text: Increase in 500 ml of FEV1 after glucocorticoids inhalation

options.label: D
options.text: Less than 20 % diurnal variation on more than 3 days a week on PEF diary

questions.correct_answer: B. Increase in FEV1 ≥ 12 % following administration of inhaled bronchodilators

questions.text: The parameters used in modified Child-Pugh classification for staging cirrhosis are:

options.label: B
options.text: Serum albumin, serum bilirubin, prothrombin time only

options.label: C
options.text: Serum albumin, serum bilirubin, prothrombin time, ascities only

options.label: D
options.text: Serum albumin, Serum bilirubin, prothrombin time, ascities, hepatic encephalopathy

questions.correct_answer: D. Serum albumin, Serum bilirubin, prothrombin time, ascities, hepatic encephalopathy

questions.text: Which of the following is the most important complication in a patient with coeliac disease, who was previously doing well on a gluten-free diet and is now not responding to gluten restriction?

questions.correct_answer: D. Liver biopsy with quantitative copper assays

questions.text: A 30-year old HIV infected male presents with shortness of breath and moderate fever of two- week duration. On examination, cyanosis is present, with respiratory rate of 22/minute and some basal crackles in chest. The CT chest shows bilateral ground-glass pattern. CD4 count are less than 200/mm3.The most likely etiologic diagnosis is:

questions.correct_answer: C. Opening snap late after S2

You did diagnostic pleural tap with the following test results- • Serum protein= 7g/dL • Pleural fluid protein=5g/dL • Serum glucose=90mg/dL • Pleural fluid glucose=20mg/dL • Pleural fluid LDH =300 units What is the likely diagnosis

A 55 -year-old male presents with memory loss, migrating joint pain, chronic diarrhea and weight loss for the past 2 years. You noticed oculo-masticatory myorhythmic movements, generalized lymphadenopathy and ascites. Anti tTG ab are negative. Which of the following statements regarding this disease is true?

options.label: C
options.text: Colonoscopy with biopsy is the diagnostic test of choice

questions.correct_answer: B. Prolonged antibiotic treatment is required

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented to the hospital with abdominal distention and jaundice. On examination- icterus and ascites is present. On lab investigations serum albumin is 3.0 g/dl. Paracentesis shows ascites fluid albumin of 0.9 g/dL, and WBC 150/mm3 with lymphocyte predominance. Which of the following is the most likely cause of ascites?
The most sensitive test to detect platelet dysfunction is

A 35 year old patient presented with gradually increasing obstructive urinary symptoms for last 2 years. He complains of thinning of urinary stream with intermittency with occasional dysuria. On P/R examination, prostate is normal in size, firm, non tender, smooth, median sulcus preserved and mucosa is mobile over it. Urine examination is normal and USGF revealed a 22 grams prostate with insignificant residual urine. There is no past history of trauma but H/O unprotected sex was there. RGU image is given below. Diagnosis of urethral stricture was made. What is the site of stricture?

A 6-year-old boy is noted to have worsening visual acuity on serial eye exams. Recent MRI of his brain and orbits reveals an optic chiasm mass, most consistent with an optic pathway glioma. Upon further examination, the physician notes axillary freckling and numerous “spots” on the patient’s skin. This patient most likely has a which of the following genetic disorders?

A 3-year-old nonsyndromic, well-appearing male with no significant past medical history presents with an abdominal mass palpated by his mother when giving him a bath. CT imaging reveals a 9-cm right renal mass without involvement of the inferior vena cava (IVC) and no evidence of tumor thrombus by ultrasound. The left kidney appears normal, and there is no imaging evidence of tumor rupture or adherence to surrounding organs. There are diffuse, bilateral pulmonary metastases from which he is asymptomatic with a normal respiratory rate and no supplemental oxygen requirement. Following the National Wilms Tumor Study Group (NWTS)/Children’s Oncology Group (COG) approach to pediatric renal tumors, which of the following are appropriate next steps?

options.label: A
options.text: Core biopsy of the renal mass followed by three drug chemotherapy—vincristine, actinomycin, and doxorubicin

options.label: B
options.text: Nephrectomy with lymph node sampling followed by chemotherapy based on histology and stage

options.label: C
options.text: Neoadjuvant three drug chemotherapy—vincristine, actinomycin and doxorubicin— followed by nephrectomy at week 6

options.label: D
options.text: Neoadjuvant three drug chemotherapy—vincristine, actinomycin, and doxorubicin— followed by diagnostic biopsy at week 6 if primary tumor is showing good response to therapy.

questions.correct_answer: B. Nephrectomy with lymph node sampling followed by chemotherapy based on histology and stage

options.label: B
options.text: Are suggested by a bile duct diameter > 8mm of ultrasound.

options.label: C
options.text: ERCP, sphincterotomy and balloon clearance is now the standard treatment.

options.text: When removed by exploration of the common bile duct the T-tube can be removed after 3 days.

questions.correct_answer: D. When removed by exploration of the common bile duct the T-tube can be removed after 3 days.

options.label: B
options.text: Hamartomatous polyps associated with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

questions.text: The following statements about thyroglossal cyst are true, except?

options.label: A
options.text: Frequent cause of anterior midline neck masses in the first decade of life.

options.label: B
options.text: The cyst is located within 2 cm of the midline.

options.label: C
options.text: Incision and Drainage is the treatment of choice.

options.label: D
options.text: The swelling moves upwards on protrusion of tongue.

questions.correct_answer: C. Incision and Drainage is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: All of the following are used for reconstruction of breast except:

He gives a past history of Cerebro vascular accident and Myocardial infarction. O/E no specific sign was observed in abdomen, only bowel sound were slightly exaggerated. Serum amylase is 250 IU. What would be the probable diagnosis?
All are true regarding inguinal canal except

options.label: A
options.text: Roof is formed by conjoint tendon.

options.label: B
options.text: Deep inguinal ring is formed by transverse abdominus.

options.label: C
options.text: Superficial inguinal ring is formed by ext. oblique. Muscle

options.label: D

questions.correct_answer: B. Deep inguinal ring is formed by transverse abdominus.

questions.text: Which endocrine abnormality is more likely in patient with GIST being treated by Sunitinib?
With regard to wound healing, which one of the following statements is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Collagen content reaches a maximum at approximately 1 week after injury.

options.label: B
options.text: Monocytes are essential for normal wound healing.

options.label: C
options.text: Fibroblasts appear in the wound within 24–36 h after the injury.

options.label: D
options.text: Early in wound healing, type I collagen is predominant.

questions.correct_answer: B. Monocytes are essential for normal wound healing.

questions.text: Regarding high-voltage electrical burns to an extremity true statement is?

options.label: A
options.text: Injuries are generally more superficial than those of thermal burns.

options.label: B
options.text: Intravenous fluid replacement is based on the percentage of body surface area burned.

options.label: D
options.text: Evaluation for fracture of the other extremities and visceral injury is indicated.

questions.correct_answer: D. Evaluation for fracture of the other extremities and visceral injury is indicated.

questions.text: Which of the following signs/symptoms are pathognomonic of hyperparathyroidism?

A 35-year-old woman presents with pancreatitis. Subsequent endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) reveals the congenital cystic anomaly of her biliary system illustrated in the film below. Which of the following statements regarding this problem is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Treatment consists of internal drainage via choledochoduodenostomy

options.label: B
options.text: Malignant changes may occur within this structure

options.label: C
options.text: Cystic dilation of the intrahepatic biliary tree may coexist and is managed in a similar fashion

options.label: D
options.text: Surgery should be reserved for symptomatic patients.

questions.correct_answer: B. Malignant changes may occur within this structure

questions.text: A full-term male newborn experiences respiratory distress immediately after birth. A prenatal sonogram had been read as normal. An emergency radiograph is shown below. The patient was intubated and placed on 100% O2. The arterial blood gas revealed pH 7.24; PO2 60 kPa; PCO2 52 kPa. The baby has sternal retractions and a scaphoid abdomen. Which of the following statements correctly refers to this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: The most likely cause of this problem is in utero traumatic rupture of the diaphragm

options.label: B
options.text: The most important aspect in management would be immediate exploration and repair of the defect

options.label: C
options.text: The size of the defect does not directly correlates with severity of the disease

options.label: D
options.text: The defect is usually anteromedial in location

questions.correct_answer: C. The size of the defect does not directly correlates with severity of the disease

questions.text: A 25 years old G2P1L1 with 14 weeks of gestation has blood pressure of 140/110 mm Hg. She has proteinuria as well. Her protein in a 24-hour urine sample is 500mg. What is your diagnosis?

questions.text: Which one of the following is not correct regarding placenta?

options.label: A

options.label: B

questions.correct_answer: C. Repeat B-HCG test after 3 days

Calculate the RR for the table given below:
In which bag of BMW will you discard the following given in the image?

A study was done in a PILOT district where it was found that efficacy of JSSK program is equivalent to SUMAN program; but the UNICEF proved it the entire state that SUMAN is more effective that JSSK. What statistical inference can be drawn for this research?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • • In reality (PILOT district), both are same; so Null hypothesis is true.
  • • • In RCT, both have been proved to be different; so alternate hypothesis is true.
  • • • We draw the Perpendicular lines and point of intersection gives the answer.
  • • • Possible Outcomes of a Screening Test/ RCT

questions.text: Which kind of relationship is shown by the SCATTER PLOT drawn below?
Effectiveness of which of the following contraceptive is not 100% as per values set by GoI?
A person was diagnosed with HIV today; tomorrow diagnosed with TB. As a medical officer which treatment would you start first?

options.label: D
options.text: Wait till the person is diagnosed with some more diseases.

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • • When both HIV and TB are diagnosed in same person it is always advisable to start ATT first for 14 days and then start ART alongside ATT.
  • • • If, we start ART first then the person will suffer from Immune Reconstitution syndrome and there would be flaring up of TB.

questions.text: A student wastes a lot of time on social media seeing reels rather than studying. HE thinks he can mug up the entire subject of PSM just before the exam. Which skill is he banking upon?
Which of the following is true regarding confounding variables and causation?

options.label: A
options.text: Confounding variables can only affect the relationship between the independent variable and the outcome variable, not causation.

options.label: B
options.text: Confounding variables can obscure or distort causal relationships between the independent variable and the outcome variable

options.label: C
options.text: Confounding variables do not have any effect on causation.

options.label: D
options.text: Confounding factors can be removed by blinding.

questions.correct_answer: B. Confounding variables can obscure or distort causal relationships between the independent variable and the outcome variable

questions.text: Which food proteins among the following are the best and are used in nutritional studies as 'reference protein'?

A 42 year old diabetic patient complain of diplopia, which was more when he sees objects to right. The doctor examines him and notices finding as in the given pic. MRI head and orbit was normal. Which is false?

options.label: A
options.text: There can be right lateral rectus palsy

options.label: B
options.text: There can be secondary contraction of right medial rectus

options.label: C
options.text: He compensates diplopia by right face turn

An injection was given inside the eye and he was advised to follow up in a week. He did not come for further evaluation after this. Few months later, he comes in with a red, painful eye and after IOP control, the following procedure was done as given in figure. Identify the procedure?

A 4-year-old girl presents for evaluation of poor vision. After completion of retinoscopy of right eye of a child, it was noted that the vertical axis power was -4 dioptres and horizontal axis was -4 dioptres. What will be the refractive error for the right eye of the child?

options.label: B
options.text: Compound hypermetropic astigmatism with the rule

options.label: C
options.text: Compound myopic astigmatism against the rule

A patient underwent a phacoemulsification with IOL in his right eye. During cataract surgery, there was posterior capsule rupture and some lens fragments were left behind. 1st post-op day, he was complaining of pain with decreased visual acuity. The following features were noted: Eyelid swelling, chemosis, conjunctival injection and discharge Corneal haze Anterior chamber: normal depth, fibrinous exudate and hypopyon Vitritis with an impaired view of the fundus What is the diagnosis?
A 12 year old boy came to OPD and an ‘egg-yolk’ type appearence was seen in the center of retina. Which investigation will be useful here?

A 29-year-old man is hospitalized due to a flulike illness. His symptoms abruptly began 3 days ago with fever, rigors, malaise, headache, and myalgia. The patient has no prior health conditions and is usually very active, participating in multiple outdoor sports. Temperature is 38.90 C, blood pressure is 124/84 mm Hg, and pulse is 110/min. Physical examination shows an ill-appearing man with bilateral conjunctival suffusion. Generalized lymphadenopathy is also present. A test for influenza antigen is negative, and blood cultures in routine growth media are negative. The patient subsequently develops progressive jaundice and renal failure. Urine microscopy with a special stain shown in the image. Choose the correct selective medium for this pathogen.

A 40-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to malaise, fever, productive cough, and pleuritic chest pain. The patient has a history of alcohol use disorder and HIV acquired from injection drug use. She is nonadherent with antiretroviral therapy and other medications. Temperature is 38.30 C, blood pressure is 120/72 mm Hg, and pulse is 104/min. Lung examination reveals bronchial breath sounds and crackles. Sputum microscopy findings are shown in the image. Which of the following pathogenic factors most likely contributes to this microorganism's ability to cause lung infection?

A 39-year-old paraplegic man with an indwelling bladder catheter comes to the emergency department complaining of 24 hours of rigors, nausea, and vomiting. His temperature is 38.90C.Physical examination shows suprapubic and costovertebral angle tenderness. Urinalysis shows 3+ leukocyte esterase and numerous white blood cells. Urine and blood cultures grow a pathogen in cetrimide agar. Choose the mechanism of action of the toxin produced by this organism.

options.label: A
options.text: Acting on 60s ribosome inhibits protein synthesis

options.label: C
options.text: Acting on EF2 inhibits protein synthesis

questions.correct_answer: C. Acting on EF2 inhibits protein synthesis

questions.text: Satellitism exhibited in blood agar by Hemophilus influenzae is due to

options.label: D
options.text: Recovery from previous infection of hepatitis B

questions.correct_answer: D. Recovery from previous infection of hepatitis B

questions.text: A man after return from complains of pain abdomen, jaundice with increased alkaline phosphatase and conjugated hyperbilirubinemia: USG shows blockade of the biliary tree. What could be the cause?

A 54-year-old man who is a farmer in rural area comes to the physician because of a chronic cough. A chest x-ray shows a mass lesion with hilar lymphadenopathy. Examination of tissue obtained on biopsy of the mass shows multiple tiny oval forms within macrophages. Which of the following is the most likely underlying condition?

The image shown here depicts Elek’s gel precipitation test which shown positive reaction for C. diphtheriae. Choose the correct name for this procedure

A 4-year-old boy is seen for evaluation of diffuse abdominal pain and poor oral intake. The pain is mild, intermittent, and colicky, but is not associated with vomiting, diarrhea, or constipation. His vital signs are stable. He developed a rash on his buttocks and legs 2 weeks ago. The rash is purpuric and has raised borders. He has nonpitting edema of the hands and ankles but no joint swelling. He has mild tenderness on palpation of the abdomen. The rest of his physical examination findings are unremarkable. Laboratory data are shown: Blood White blood cell count 8,100/μL (8.1 × 109/L) Hemoglobin 12.1 g/dL (121 g/L) Platelet count 400 × 103/μL (400 × 109/L) Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 110 mm/h Blood urea nitrogen 14 mg/dL (5.0 mmol/L) Creatinine 0.5 mg/dL (44 μmol/L) Aspartate aminotransferase 36 U/L Alanine aminotransferase 38 U/L Serum albumin 3.8 g/dL (38 g/L) Urine -Blood 3+ -Red blood cells 20-50/HPF -Protein 1+ A stool guaiac test has negative results. Of the following, the MOST appropriate initial treatment for this patient is
Which of the following is not an indication of steroids in IgA vasculitis?

A 4-year-old boy is being evaluated for unusual movements and concerning neurologic findings. He displays dystonia, choreoathetosis, and spasticity. His parents report that he has had low tone and global developmental delay since 3 months of age. He was diagnosed with cerebral palsy at 2 years of age. He is nonverbal and exhibits increasingly frequent banging of his head and biting of his fingers, hands, and lips. He is nondysmorphic in appearance. A maternal male cousin has similar clinical findings. Genetic and biochemical screening is performed. Of the following, the test MOST likely to suggest this boy’s diagnosis is

A 5-day-old full-term male neonate is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of poor feeding. His parents report that in the past day he seems to tire while feeding. He had been eating well over the prior 48 hours. On physical examination, the neonate is cyanotic and tachypneic, but appears comfortable. His heart rate is 160 beats/min, respiratory rate is 60 breaths/min, blood pressure is 70/40 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 60% on room air. Chest radiograph is shown Of the following, the BEST next management step for this neonate is to
Which of the following drug is not used in a cyanotic spell in TOF?

An infant born at 32 weeks of gestation with a birth weight of 1,400 g is evaluated for discharge from the neonatal intensive care unit. His mother had chronic hypertension. He is now 4 weeks old and weighs 2,100 g. On physical examination, there is no murmur and slightly increased lower extremity muscle tone. He remains comfortable in room air and is feeding expressed breast milk with 2 feedings per day of formula. Of the following, the screening test MOST likely to be recommended before discharge is
A newborn is born at 28 weeks gestation, and a birth weight of 1500gms. What is the best time for eye check up in this baby?

A black male infant is born at term after a pregnancy with no complications. On routine predischarge screening at 36 hours of age, he is noted to have room air oxygen saturation of 98% on pulse oximetry in his right upper extremity and 93% in his right lower extremity. He is vigorous and nursing well. The remainder of his physical examination findings are normal. Of the following, the MOST appropriate next management step for this neonate is to

options.label: A
options.text: Discharge him with instructions to return in 2 days for follow-up

options.label: B
options.text: Observe him for an additional 24 hours before discharge

questions.correct_answer: D. Repeat pulse oximetry in 1 hour

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is being evaluated for fevers and malaise. She has had recurrent low-grade fevers, decreased energy, decreased appetite, and increased fussiness over the past 3 weeks. She was limping for 2 days early in the illness, and has complained of leg pain over the past 3 days. Her parents report a rash on her face that they attribute to a sunburn. On physical examination, the girl is mildly ill appearing. Her temperature is 38.1°C, heart rate is 80 beats/min, respiratory rate is 18 breaths/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. She has lost 3 kg since her health supervision visit 3 months ago. She has a facial rash (Item Q97) and several shallow painless ulcers on her buccal mucosa. The remainder of her physical examination findings are unremarkable. Of the following, the MOST common complication of this girl’s likely diagnosis is

A 7-year-old boy is admitted to the hospital with fever and headache. He has congenital hydrocephalus and a ventriculoperitoneal shunt. He takes phenytoin at home to prevent seizures. He is receiving intravenous vancomycin every 6 hours for suspected shunt infection. On day 2 of admission, he has decreased urine output. His vital signs are stable, and he has no swelling over the face or ankles. He is alert and oriented without any neurological deficit. The rest of the physical examination findings are unremarkable. Laboratory data are shown: Sodium 134 mEq/L (134 mmol/L) Potassium 4.8 mEq/L (4.8 mmol/L) Chloride 100 mEq/L (100 mmol/L) Bicarbonate 20 mEq/L (20 mmol/L) Blood urea nitrogen 25 mg/dL (8.9 mmol/L) Creatinine 2 mg/dL (177 μmol/L) Vancomycin, trough level 54 μg/mL (37 μmol/L) Of the following, the additional laboratory finding MOST likely to be seen in this patient is

options.label: A
options.text: Fractional excretion of sodium more than 2%

options.label: B
options.text: Red blood cell casts on microscopic urinalysis

options.label: C
options.text: Specific gravity of urine more than 1.020

options.label: D
options.text: Urine to plasma osmolality ratio more than 1.5

questions.correct_answer: A. Fractional excretion of sodium more than 2%

questions.text: A patient with a history of bilateral profound sensorineural hearing loss, lack of vestibular function, and progressive retinal deterioration is scheduled for an audiological assessment.Which etiology is consistent with the patient’s history?

questions.text: A six-month-old child born with bilateral bony atresia is seen for an audiological evaluation and treatment recommendation. Radiological evidence indicates the probable presence of an intact middle ear and cochlea.ABR responses have been obtained at near-normal levels to bone-conducted signals. Of the following, the most appropriate course of action for this child at this time would be to

options.label: A
options.text: Defer treatment until growth of the external and middle ear is complete at about age 6

options.label: B
options.text: Suggest that surgery be initiated on at least one ear to permit a normal air-conducted pathway

options.label: C
options.text: Investigate the use of a bone-conduction hearing aid until audiological test results can be confirmed and surgery initiated when the child is older

options.label: D
options.text: Counsel the parents concerning sign language and initiate a treatment program based on the use of all visual cues

questions.correct_answer: C. Investigate the use of a bone-conduction hearing aid until audiological test results can be confirmed and surgery initiated when the child is older

options.label: A

questions.correct_answer: A. With increase in pressure in External auditory canal, there is decrease in the intensity of bone conducted sound in normal individuals
